messageBody:
Hi Per,

That's totally helpful.

There is a command-line version from an earlier prototype, and I had
just been keeping it out for now to simplify, but I plan on bringing
that back.

Adding an ignore list seems like a reasonable way to provide filtering
too. I could see it being used from Eclipse, Ant or the commandline.

As to setting a threshold, it sounds like a regression-detector sort
of feature as opposed to customizing the crap threshold itself. Is
that correct?

Bob Evans

http://www.crap4j.org/
Know Your Code CRAP Score

On Nov 16, 2007, at 10:46 AM, Per Jacobsson wrote:

> I'd like something really simple, ideally not tied to Eclipse or
> Ant. I use a mix of Maven 1, Ant and shell scripts for builds, and
> some people here prefer to write code in IntelliJ or even vim. My
> suggestion would be an external file, crap4j.config perhaps, in the
> classpath somewhere, and have it contain entries like:
>
> Ignore:
> com.pjacobsson.crap.*
> com.pjacobsson.SomeClass
> com.pjacobsson.SomeOtherClass.crappyMethod
>
> An @Ignore annotation on class or method level could be a nice
> addition for some cases, but it should be optional. I'd prefer to
> not have dependencies from the code to tools like crap4j, at least
> not in an early stage.
>
> Also, it could be useful to be able to set an "acceptable CRAP
> score" on method level, and if it goes above that the method should
> show up in the reports. Just to make sure that bad code doesn't get
> any worse.
>
> Hope that's useful.
> / Per
>
